statement.text: Anatomic bypass follows the native arterial pathway while extra-anatomic bypass routes the graft through non-anatomic tissue planes, with anatomic generally preferred for durability and extra-anatomic used for hostile abdomens or infection.
statement.formal: Bypass_Type: Anatomic (native path, better patency) vs Extra-Anatomic (avoids abdomen, lower patency)

explanation.intuition: Anatomic bypass is like rebuilding the same highway in the same location - it's durable but requires going through the usual territory (abdomen). Extra-anatomic is like building an alternate route around a problem area - less direct but avoids trouble spots.
explanation.key_insight: Anatomic bypasses (aortofemoral, aortoiliac) have superior long-term patency (90% at 5 years) but require abdominal surgery. Extra-anatomic bypasses (axillo-femoral, fem-fem) avoid the abdomen but have lower patency (50-70% at 5 years).
explanation.technical_details: Anatomic examples: aortobifemoral, aortoiliac, femoral-popliteal in Hunter's canal. Extra-anatomic examples: axillobifemoral, femorofemoral, obturator bypass. Indications for extra-anatomic: hostile abdomen, severe cardiac risk, infected aortic graft, aortoenteric fistula. Patency: anatomic 85-90% at 5 years, axillofemoral 50-70%, femfem 70-85%.

clinical_pearls: Anatomic bypasses have better long-term patency but require abdominal surgery
Consider extra-anatomic for hostile abdomen, graft infection, or prohibitive cardiac risk
Fem-fem bypass has best extra-anatomic patency (70-85% at 5 years)
